dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE GOINES turns to the Jury FOREMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Foreman, have you arrived at a verdict?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have, your honor.  We find the defendant guilty of all the charges.

dialogues.speaker: THE DEFENDANT, BERNIE LAPLANTE
dialogues.text: Forty, rumpled, cheap suit, cheap haircut.  He reacts, tu to the jury, indignant. His attorney, DONNA O'DAY, rises.  She's twenty-four, loo younger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your honor, may I approach the bench? As BERNIE fumes, the JUDGE, DONNA and the youthful clean- PROSECUTOR engage in an earnest, inaudible discussion. Frustrated, Bernie is watching them when he notices somet that distracts him from his anguish. Donna's wallet is lying in her open attache case.  The op of the case screens the wallet from the view of the JURY, JUDGE, COURT REPORTERS, etc. Bernie looks around, checking the spectators section. No spectators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernie gets the wallet to his lap.  In between cautious g toward the bench where the conference continues inaudibly surreptitiously selects some of the twenties and some of tens from the wallet.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BENCH
dialogues.text: The conference breaks up, DONNA heads back toward the def table. The wallet still concealed in his lap under the table, BE is indignant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?  "Guilty"!  What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got your bail continued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bail, for Chrissake!  I'm innocent! The JUDGE gavels for order as BERNIE slips DONNA's "light wallet back into her attache case unseen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister LaPlante, I have been persuaded in view of your continued employment and your lack of prior convictions, to continue your bail under the same conditions heretofore, pending sentencing six days from now.  In the meantime you will make an appointment with the probation officer who will make a recommendation to me regarding your sentence.  I urge you to use these six days to set your personal affairs in order in anticipation of incarceration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERNIE and DONNA are hurrying along the crowded corridor the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Anticipation of incarceration"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (upset)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He means prison, Mr. LaPlante.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what he means.  I'm not a prison kinda guy, Miss O'Day.  I'm a goddamn working man for Chrissake!  Maybe I "augment" my income a little with some "business deals," maybe summa the guys I sell to are crooks, how would I know, I'm not an investigator.  You can't make it on a wage no more, not in this country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think our best course right now would be to focus on the Probation Officer's report...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives a good report and I walk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can hope. (consulting her notes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still have your job, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I been calling in sick.  They think I got the flu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a son by your ex-wife?  Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A son, yeah.  What about him?  Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you pretty involved in his upbringing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Involved!  Christ!  She attached my goddamn paycheck!  Child support. Why do you think I can't afford a lawyer? (then...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean.  Why I got a court appointed lawyer instead of a, uh, more experienced...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.  How often do you see your son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Often, uh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How recently?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, his birthday, uh, May.  I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's November.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat... beat... beat...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She don't like me to see him. Says I'm a bad influence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should visit your son. And try and get your boss to write a note about your performance on the job.  You need to create the impression of a responsible, decent citizen with familial responsibilities who happened to slip up once. They have reached the front door.  BERNIE nods, about to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with difficulty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I know you're having financial difficulties, Mister LaPlante, but I wonder if... I mean, the money I loaned you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of it.  Right here.  I got some of it.  I'll get the rest as soon as I can. BERNIE pulls out the crumpled bills he took from Donna's and hands them to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised and touched)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know things are difficult for you, Mister LaPlante.  I don't want to take your last dime... BERNIE is already reaching for a twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  I better keep some if I'm gonna see the kid.  For gas and stuff. Then, unable to resist the chance, he snatches another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LION lies glumly in his cage, staring balefully through bars at BERNIE who stares balefully back, contemplating t bars.  At BERNIE'S side is a ten year old boy, JOEY, whos scrubbed appearance is in sharp contrast to BERNIE'S rump slightly soiled look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow!  Look at that one! JOEY is indicating the next cage where a BLACK PANTHER is restlessly to and fro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were in there, he'd kill you, wouldn't he...Dad? As Bernie looks at the PANTHER, the muscular beast looks into BERNIE'S eyes with the furious yellow stare as if to "I'm waiting."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERNIE and JOEY facing each other in a booth, eating burg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy, this "friend" your mother's seeing, he's a fireman, huh?  He ever... spend the night, whatsisname?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes.  His name's Elliot.  He saved a guy's life one time.  In a fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?  A hero, huh? (a beat, then...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he in the 'Nam, this guy Elliot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Nomm"?  What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was this war.  Viet Nam.  Doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you in it?  In the war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never saw that picture, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What picture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me in my uniform.  Used to be on the bookcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deserted except for BERNIE and JOEY side by side at the u BERNIE glances at JOEY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha gotta do there, buddy, is ya gotta get in close so ya don't piss on yer shoes. It don't matter now cause you're wearin' them sneakers but the time's gonna come when you're gonna be wearin' good shoes, expensive ones, and you don't wanna piss on them, you wanna protect 'em.  From piss, from tough guys, from everything. -- ALTERNATE VERSION --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I don't like about public restrooms is how you're always standing in piss.  It don't matter to you, you got those sneakers but I'm standing in piss in very expensive shoes.  It's a breakdown in custodial services. JOEY steals a glance at BERNIE, sees him "shake it off" a up.  JOEY does likewise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you gonna take me somewhere next weekend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm working on that.  It's just I got some business problems and... whatsa matter? JOEY is heading for one of the stalls.  He reaches undern and pulls out a wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody lost a wallet. BERNIE is extremely interested, takes the wallet JOEY hol and glances inside. Cash.  A couple of fifties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERNIE and JOEY exit the Men's Room and head for the door the parking lot, BERNIE explaining...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You give it to the manager, he pockets the dough, throws the wallet away.  Most people who work in supervisory positions... I'm not saying all... are crooks. JOEY casts a hasty glance at TEENAGER who's wearing the Manager Badge.  The youth could not look more innocent if wore a halo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BAG LADY pushing two shopping carts through the parking spots BERNIE and JOEY crossing her path...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir, could you spare...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way, lady, not a chance. BERNIE hurries past her, notices JOEY looking back at the miserable woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta resist the urge to be nice to those people, they're con artists, they take advantage of the soft heart.  A lot of 'em are financially better off than the rest of us. Arriving at an ancient, battered Toyota, BERNIE searches his keys and then fusses with the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'm gonna do on this wallet thing is, Monday, day after tomorrow, I'm gonna have my secretary phone this guy up from the name on his driver's license Let the guy come and get his wallet and make sure you get a reward. You deserve a reward.  You want one, doncha?  A reward?  Gwan, get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERNIE is at the wheel, the car is gasping, struggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha gotta do, you gotta look out for number one.  It sounds harsh, but it's a goddamn (excuse the vulgarity) jungle out there, kid.  That's why you gotta keep a low profile!  Right?  A low profile! It's where you don't give nobody nothin' to shoot at, stay outta sight, be parta the woodwork, don't ever tell 'em your name, they'll use it against you. JOEY is looking for the right exit sign.  He spots it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.  Get off here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a look at Joey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  Thanks, pal. JOEY looks pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERNIE is turning onto a suburban street, checking the ho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, buddy, I'm really enjoying this relationship we got going here. I been missing out on not knowing you better.  Thing is, I got all this business stuff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could go to a movie Thursday night.  'Cause we don't have school on Friday. BERNIE pulls the car up in front of a single story two be house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we are.  Yeah, that's a possibility.  A movie.  Now you gwan in, tell your mother I got you back on time.  Point that out to her. She was always on my case for stuff like that.  She's still like that, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little grin, his first)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (getting out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see ya... dad. JOEY gets out and runs toward the house.  BERNIE watches go.  Then he pulls out the wallet, thumbs the cash, glanc the credit cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bored, fiftyish bartender, CHICK, is watching the TV over the bar in this unfashionable, nearly-deserted joint looks up when the door opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernie!  Where ya been, Pal? Arriving at the bar, BERNIE surveys the dimly lit room, c the booths and tables for customers.  Not many.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some guys been looking for me, Chick?  Spanish kinda guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spanish kinda guys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business thing.  Gimme a seven and seven, willya? BERNIE checks his watch, takes a seat, puts a twenty on t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, five days now I don't see you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I'm up to my ass in shit is why.  I'm broke, plus I got legal problems... Nobody was asking for me, huh? BERNIE looks around nervously, peering into the shadowy b and rear tables as CHICK puts a drink in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.  Legal problems, you gotta have a good attorney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My attorney, she's just outta law school, about a couple of years older than my kid, for Chrissake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta kid?  How old's your kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine.  I think.  Maybe ten.  Yeah, ten.  Nice kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a ten year old attorney, Bernie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't afford no better.  My ex, she attached my pay check for child support payments. (turning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You looking for Bernie LaPlante by any chance? A MAN who's just entered the lounge shakes his head no an for a table where he's greeted by the COCKTAIL WAITRESS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't even know you had a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing about kids is, they're so... young!  They don't know nothin' yet.  When you're a kid, you think you're gonna grow up an' be a "wonderful person" instead of an asshole, like everybody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all assholes, Bernie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was a kid, I thought I was gonna be this fantastic wonderful heroic human being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You Bernie Planta? BERNIE turns. Two Latinos are right behind him, low lifes, ESPINOSA and VARGAS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LaPlante.  Bernie LaPlante.  You the guys Bunny called, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Credit cards are being inspected.  ESPINOSA, seated betwe VARGAS and BERNIE, in a booth in the nearly deserted loun looks the cards over dubiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three hours is old, man.  Very old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, he might not of reported 'em at all yet.  He might not know for a couple hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pick his pocket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, more or less.  Trust me, these are very very fresh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEFFREY BROADMAN is standing against the granite facade o downtown office building.  Three thousand dollar suit, He tie, expensively cut silver grey hair ruffling slightly i breeze.  Charming smile, candid eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be honest, I can't make sense of it either, Ms. Gayley. Things seem to be on the upswing, our differences with the SEC have been favorably resolved.  In a business sense, I believe we've "turned the corner..." GALE GAYLEY, a TV reporter, is standing close to BROADMAN microphone in her hand.  She's thirty, attractive, dignif We can hear SIRENS in the distance and, closer, the CRACK of radios and walkie talkies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Broadman, your wife and children are on their way here as we speak.  Don't you think -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel I've done very well in life: good health, wonderful family, much wealth.  I guess what we're talking about here is a kind of despair.  I just have the feeling that everything from here on is going to be... downhill... At a time like this, I think I'm entitled, as the saying goes, to "look out for number one" and put my own needs first.  That pretty much concludes what I have to say. Thanks for coming out here to let me talk to you and your viewers. A nice smile as he drops RIGHT OUT THE BOTTOM OF THE FRAM

dialogues.speaker: GALE
dialogues.text: Looking down, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god!  Chucky, tilt down. Her cameraman, CHUCKY, twenty-five, is already urgently t his vidpak as WE REVEAL that he and GALE are standing on many stories above the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get it? (then, doubly horrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, did I say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got it.  Sports training. You learn to follow the ball. (looking up at Gale)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you do a wrap-up from up here?  I'll pan off that skyscraper over there, find you here, then reveal the drop. GALE looks shaken.

dialogues.speaker: TV IMAGE, (EXT. OFFICE BUILDING LEDGE - DAY)
dialogues.text: Later, the CAMERA "finds" GALE in mid-sentence standing o ledge, "wearing" her broadcast voice and persona...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suicide number 137 of this year in this city was neither a destitute nor a lonely man, but a successful executive with a loving family and forty million dollars in the bank.  If there's nameless "despair" in executive offices, what can there be sixty stories below where the hungry and the homeless, the brutalized and the addicted, fight their daily battle for survival. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a ledge sixty stories above the street, I'm Gale Gayley for Channel Four News.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEAKINS, fifty, shirtsleeves, News Director, and WALLACE, Station Manager, suit and tie, patrician, are watching th monitor while CHUCKY and PARKER, the boyish gofer, hover them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whadja think of the fall shot, Chief?  The guy drops twenty stories in perfect focus, center frame while I go smoothly from F16 to F5.6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helluva shot, Chucky, beautiful. (pulling out the video tape)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parker, run this down to Frazier, tell him we open with it at six, eleven and at seven a.m.... PARKER is already running out the door as Gale enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Chief.  You like the suicide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never reach out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mister Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gale)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right.  It's unprofessional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gale)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you reach out, you could get pulled over yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're we talking about?  Reach out for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told them how you were upset we didn't save the guy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saving people is not our job.  It's as wrong to step in and save someone as it would be to push someone off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't push the guy, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say I thought we should have saved him..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I wished it had at least occurred to me to consider saving him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What good would that do? GALE sits on Deakins' desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would make me feel like a human being instead of a cynical, hardbitten newswoman.  Besides it wouldn't be a bad story, would it, "Newswoman Saves Suicide?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unprofessional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just can't bear the idea of good news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sitting on your ticket. GALE finds an envelope on the desk under her butt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ticket!  What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's flying to New York.  She's been nominated for a Silver Mike...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Silver Mike!  You're covering us in glory!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't won it yet. (studying ticket, to Deakins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I notice you've got me scheduled on a flight back an hour after the ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour after...!  Deak, for Heaven's sake!  Let's give her a night in New York City.  We'll put her and her boyfriend up at a good hotel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She broke up with her boyfriend. (to Gale)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, babe, we needja back. You gotta follow up on the jumper, find the human interest in the grim, unending tale of woe that pours from the wounded heart of the heartless metropolis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The story behind the story, the ugly scandal behind the falling millionaire, the dirt, you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Wallace)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would the station put me up at a good hotel...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a look toward Deakins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely! GALE gives DEAKINS a big grin and starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, hell with it.  Party hearty... is that what they say?  I'll figure something out. (once she's gone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's just pretending she's a person.  She's really a reporter. Fifty bucks she's on the first flight back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I don't get?  I don't get why a guy who's gonna jump asks to talk to a TV reporter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause how's he gonna know he's jumped if it's not on the six o'clock news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HORNS BLARE as a FORD VAN cuts off a CAB and squirms into parking place marked "HANDICAPPED ONLY." The side of the van reads GUMLEY'S SUPER CARPET CARE and features a cartoon logo and a phone number. BERNIE, wearing Gumley overalls, jumps out of the van and hurries up the steps to an imposing municipal building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door reads "PROBATION DEPARTMENT."  MOVE IN ON THE DOOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernie is sitting across the desk from the stone-faced, b Probation Officer, PATRICK DUKE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agitated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  Do I have a record?  Have I ever done time?  I mean I been arrested a few times, who hasn't? Parking tickets for Chrissake! Suspicion of stuff!  Have I ever been convicted of anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister LaPlante...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look at my employment record, you got my employment record there, right?  You see any unemployment there, any welfare? I'm a taxpayer.  They eat me alive, the tax people, they got taxes on everything, taxes, taxes, taxes, and forms!  Taxes and forms so I can pay your goddamn salary, so you can sit there and write stuff, guys like me pay your wages...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister LaPlante...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I hit anybody?  You see me shoot anybody?  Hey, drugs!  Do I sell drugs?  Jesus, I don't belong in prison.  I'm a family man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister LaPlante...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I got this kid.  We got a goddamn relationship!  I'm takin' him to a movie tonight!  He worships me.  If I go down what's this do to my son?  I'm his goddamn role model for Christ sake! DUKE looks up at the "family man's" plaintive look.  Then Bernie ruins it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, if I coulda afforded an experienced attorney, I woulda walked.  It was a shitty case, very circumstantial.  You gonna send me downstate for having an inexperienced lawyer?  How you gonna feel about the system if you do that? The brief flash of mercy is gone from DUKE'S eyes, replac with a hard glitter.  BERNIE has just shot himself in the foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIGOROUS APPLAUSE!  GALE has just received the Silver Mik Award, a tastefully small, mike-sized replica of a microp from the MASTER OF CEREMONIES.  Clutching it, she faces t applauding AUDIENCE across a podium, speaking into a real microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, very much.  I'm grateful for this.  Since you're all colleagues here, you know what kind of a team it takes... to put a story on a screen.  I don't have to explain to you how much the cameraman, the editor, the assignment editor and the news director, to mention a few did to get me this award. GALE pauses.  She reaches into her purse and pulls out an She holds it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an onion. (dramatic pause, then...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a metaphor for a news story. Only a few hours ago I was standing on a ledge sixty stories above a street interviewing a man who subsequently jumped to his death. Forty million dollars in the bank, happily married, good health.  Great story! The AUDIENCE is attentive, mesmerized as they watch her r the outer skin of the onion and toss it dramatically asid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's gotta be more.  We're pros, right?  Some kinda extramarital hanky panky, maybe?  Another good story! (she peels another layer of onion)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the guy's been accused of child molesting.  Terrific story! (she peels more off the onion)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it turns out the accusation was false.  Wonderful!  More story. The AUDIENCE watches, captivated as the onion gets smalle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the alleged mistress was lying, setting the guy up. Sensational story! (the onion is very small)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We keep going, keep digging, keep investigating.  We expose the guy's whole life, his family. Why?  Because we're pros! Because... (she pauses dramatically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: we're looking for the truth! GALE considers the tiny remains of the onion in her hand. Then, she peels it down to nothing and lets it fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what if, after all our digging, after all our painstaking investigation, what if it turns out there wasn't any truth?  Just  stories!  One story after another, one layer, then another layer, until there's nothing left.  And if it's like that, do we have any. obligation to stop at any point? Or do we just keep going, digging, digging, digging, peeling, peeling, peeling, until we've peeled it all away, until we've destroyed what we were investigating in the first place?

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: attentive, as GALE pauses dramatically, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet all of you, like me, yearn for just one story that isn't about uncovering layer after layer of human weakness; a story that reveals with each new layer of investigation, something finer and nobler, something even... inspirational. GALE gazes soberly across the podium at the AUDIENCE.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION IMAGE, (EXT. SKID ROW STREETS - DAY)
dialogues.text: A BAG LADY addresses the camera, a news interview.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First rule out here on the streets is you gotta watch out for number one.  If you go down... break a bone or something... you're gone! Nobody's gonna pick you up.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shitty color!  Looka the skin tones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON, fifty and fat, is scowling at the image on the T screen in BERNIE'S spartan and tasteless three room apart BERNIE grabs the remote from WINSTON'S pudgy hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chrissake!  Homeless people are supposed to have shitty skin tones. Look! BERNIE points the remote at the screen...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: CLICK!  A gunfight replaces the BAG LADY ON SCREEN, then sitcom, an old movie, MTV, and finally a slick commercial featuring a sexy bikinied BLONDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you go!  Skin tones!  Listen, you gotta fish or cut bait.  I wouldn't even do this if I didn't have these legal problems.  Two fifty.  That's it.  I gotta get outta here, I gotta take my kid to the movies tonight, I'm late. WINSTON stares at the lithe thighs ON THE SCREEN as BERNI starts rummaging urgently in his closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go two hundred. BERNIE has just found his good shoes, notices a carton of new jackets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred!  How about a jacket? Wanna buy me a jacket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engines drone as we look into the sparsely populated cabin of the "baby Boeing".  Among the many empty seats, FLETCHER reads a magazine while his ten year son RICHIE p a pocket video game. LESLIE SUGAR, one of the two Flight Attendants, is servin drink to Mr. Smith, a businessman while FREDDY, the other Attendant, is giving a pillow to an ELDERLY WOMAN. We DISCOVER GALE, cradling a phone to her ear while she awkwardly fishes in her purse and pulls out the Silver Mi Award.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very nice actually. (reading the  inscription)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "For Excellence in the Pursuit of Truth."  Uh, listen, I just wanted you to know I got a seat back on the early flight after all so... What? Reacting to what she hears on the phone, GALE overturns t purse in her lap and the contents -- wallet, comb, lipsti notepad, etc. -- spill on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean you gave it to Conklin?  Conklin wasn't on that ledge!  Conklin wasn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEAKINS is grinning into his phone, winking at WALLACE wh standing beside his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gale, you were gonna do the town, remember?  Fancy suite at the station's expense, see a show, get laid maybe.  What was I supposed to do? Still grinning, he breaks off and listens to Gale's faint audible response while holding out his palm to WALLACE in triumphant "pay me" gesture.  Then he speaks into the pho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, you get back tonight, doll, and I'll take Conklin off your suicide.  Fly carefully... and congratulations on the award. DEAKINS hangs up and smugly pockets the fifty WALLACE has from his wallet, chuckling gleefully...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd I tell ya!  They're all like that, the good ones.  They're junkies for the story.  They can't let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eight-year-old, KELLY, seated next to GALE is helping pick up the contents of her purse from the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Very much. KELLY beams.  And GALE gives a look to KELLY'S mother SUS who's seated on the other side of KELLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's another credit card on the floor. GALE reaches down to pick up her Visa card from the floor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. GALE inserts the Visa Card in her wallet with the other c

dialogues.text: BERNIE is at the wheel, trying to see through the rain sw windshield.  He's talking to himself as he drives...

dialogues.text: I know why it's raining.  I coulda predicted this.  It's raining because my wipers are fucked up. If my wipers were okay, the fucking sun would be shining right now. At night!

dialogues.text: Engines DRONE monotonously.  The Flight Engineer is looki magazine while the PILOT and CO-PILOT, surrounded by glow instruments, stare into the blackness ahead... until some catches the bored PILOT'S eye.  A red light on the contro panel.  He frowns and looks closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for exit signs, BERNIE can barely see through the of rain that his malfunctioning wipers do little to clear Suddenly a sign looms into view and disappears before he read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engines drone.  The cabin is peaceful, most PASSENGER dozing or talking softly as GALE glances up from her maga sees SUSAN reading while KELLY sleeps peacefully, her hea SUSAN'S lap. PING!  The electronic tone.  Gale looks up, sees the "Fas Seat Belt" sign illuminated. GALE looks toward the dark window.  No sign of any lights No city.  No airport.  strange. The P.A. SYSTEM comes to life and the CAPTAIN'S mellifluo VOICE murmurs soothingly...

dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen, this is your Captain.  We're experiencing a high reading on one of our indicators. Ten to one, it's a malfunction in a gauge, but just as a precaution I'm going to ask you to fasten your seat belts while the Flight Attendants run through some safety procedures with you.  I apologize for the necessity and the inconvenience. Murmurs in the cabin.  What does this mean?  SUSAN looks question at GALE, puzzled as Flight Attendants LESLIE and take their positions to demonstrate safety procedures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First make sure your seat belts are fastened securely.  Then brace your arms against the seat ahead at you like this.  You can use pillows or blankets...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy, what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's going to be fine, honey. GALE'S eyes meet SUSAN'S eyes.  Fear.  Brave smile.

dialogues.text: Pulling off the freeway, BERNIE peers at the signs that g him as he slows to a stop at the foot of the exit. Unable to read them through the windshield he has to open door and stand in the rain. Even then, the sign is obscured by torrents of rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes are on LESLIE as she continues her instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- when you reach the bottom of the chute you should immediately move as far away from the plane as possible in the event of a fire on the aircraft. Glancing around, GALE glimpses pale, strained FACES. She sees the ELDERLY WOMAN holding the arm of a man, her She sees a MRS. BROWN squeezing a MR. BROWN'S hand tightl Looking back down the aisle she sees MR. FLETCHER putting arm around RICHIE'S shoulder, father and son united again fate. Beside her she sees SUSAN trying to comfort KELLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those of you who can should help others who may be unable to move quickly. GALE is acutely aware that everyone around her is comfort someone else.  Only she is alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at the wheel, BERNIE is turning right onto an unlit highway, his single headlight stabbing weakly at the stor while his useless wipers clatter loudly and the engine ch farts... misses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm late already!  Don't quit on me now, for Chrissake!  This ain't the time! The engine struggles, continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, come on ! The engine surges to life again... then begins to throb w downright vigor. BERNIE frowns.  It's getting louder. AND LOUDER!  AND LOUDER!  IT'S ROARING. BERNIE'S eyes bug with the realization that either he's a to take off... OR THAT ISN'T HIS ENGINE THUNDERING, THUND A great shadow blurs in the rain ahead. BERNIE brakes hard, skidding, sliding wildly.

dialogues.speaker: BAWHOOOOOOOOM
dialogues.text: BERNIE skids to a halt, eyes shut tight to prevent himsel dying. But he's not dead.  He opens his eyes.  Stares out the windshield. A blank wall greets him, bouncing back his headlights in of rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERNIE gets out of his car.  Everything is spooky quiet. The tail section of a huge aircraft blocks the road direc in front of Bernie's car.  He skidded to a stop two feet of ramming the twenty-five foot high vertical fin.  The r of the craft is sprawled off the low bridge and into the lost for the most part in the darkness. Suddenly, a VOICE calls out... from somewhere forward alo fuselage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  Help!  Somebody!  Help. BERNIE frowns.  Helping is not his instinct.  Approaching edge of the bridge, he peers into the darkness. The plane is corkscrewed through the bridge at such a fre angle that the tail rear doors are wedged shut by the met super-structure, the wing exits are blocked by the up-ben stubs, and the right forward doors are canted hopelessly the sky while the left exit is partially jammed in the mu the river bank in three feet of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please!  Help us.  We're stuck. Hello!  Anybody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatsa problem, pal?

dialogues.speaker: INT. MAIN CABIN/727 AT REST
dialogues.text: Engulfed in darkness except for strings of floor lights l to the exits, the cabin is a confusion of GROANS, COUGHS, and the piercing WAIL of a screaming BABY.  The floor lig seem to be on the walls, high on one side and low on the as the cabin is dramatically canted, making movement alon aisles nearly impossible. LESLIE, battered from the impact, her uniform torn, is struggling to open the forward emergency exit.  Angled do the door will only open six inches before being blocked b Water pours in around her ankles as she shoves furiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody give me a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's stay calm, everybody. Everybody, stay calm, please. Please stay calm.  Everything will be all right if we stay calm. Somebody give me a hand with this door. Her flashlight stabs the darkness, reveals frightened FAC Slumped, motionless forms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help the people around you, everybody.  Please help each other. AAAAAAAAAH!  SCREAMS as the plane suddenly shifts violent the interior movement, canting further.

dialogues.speaker: GALE
dialogues.text: Staggering from her seat.  WHAM!  Hand luggage slams into from an overhead rack.  As GALE goes down, a PASSENGER la on top of her catching her arm at an angle, breaking it. PASSENGER climbs off her and struggles down the slope. GALE realizes she can't get up, her leg is wedged in the framework of a seat.  PASSENGERS are climbing past her, h forward. SUSAN is fighting her way out of her canted seats, clutch the terrified KELLY to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I can't move.  I'm caught. SUSAN glances at her and their eyes meet.  KELLY is screa SUSAN turns away from GALE and half-carries KELLY toward exit, leaving GALE alone, trapped, in pain and fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERNIE is climbing cautiously down the undercarriage of t bridge toward the water, as OTHER VOICES callout from the twisted fuselage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on there, hold on there.  Just a minute. BERNIE is awkward and... very careful... climbing down, n brave or dashing.  He doesn't notice that, behind him, wh the plane is corkscrewed through the bridge a BOUQUET OF FLAMES IS BLOSSOMING IN THE FUSELAGE OF THE JET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thick smoke is oozing through the cabin.  PASSENGERS are stumbling over each other, clogging the canted aisles whi OTHERS slump in their seats, immobilized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy!  Daddy!  Daddy, wake up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep calm!  Everybody, keep calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's coming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having reached the riverbank, BERNIE is reluctant to step the water.  He hesitates, then he takes off his shoes, lo in the darkness for a place to leave them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help us!  Help, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on, buddy.  I got hundred dollar shoes here. More cries.  BERNIE steps cautiously into the water.  Up ankles.  Deeper. BERNIE wades along the huge fuselage, toward the VOICES, stumbling, landing on all fours in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! Struggling to his feet, hands muddy, he blunders toward t Emergency Exit and finds it canted into the water, jammed the mud so that it only opens a crack. MR. BROWN is wedged in the crack, trying to force the doo without success.  Glimpsing BERNIE'S hands in the crack, pleads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help us, please.  We can't get out. BERNIE makes a tentative attempt to open the door.  He ha effect whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Push it!  You gotta push hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whaddaya (grunt) think I'm (grunt) doing? Reluctantly BERNIE digs his feet into the mud, puts his s into the door and shoves with all his might.  Because he better angle on the door and better purchase, he's actual to move it several inches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harder.  Push it harder. BERNIE leans back into the door again and pushes with all might.  It gives ever so slightly.  Another inch.  MR. BR is trying to squeeze out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again!  Harder.  Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grunting with effort)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... pushing... it, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harder!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... pushing... it... asshole!

dialogues.text: PASSENGERS stumble over each other while a flashlight mak panicky stabs at the darkness, RICHIE cries out for FLETC to wake up, the BABY screams. Someone's trying to get out the overhead exit, others are hammering at an aft exit. GALE slumped in her seat, fades in and out of consciousne Above her, across the canted aisle, SUSAN is calling out help... Then, GALE'S eyes flicker with awareness at the s of an urgent shout...

dialogues.speaker: HE'S OPENING IT
dialogues.text: A sudden shadowy surge of movement in the darkness, PASSE urgently scrambling over seats toward the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERNIE gives a great heave and goes down in the river fac first. He's opened the door just wide enough for MR. BROWN to sq through the narrow opening, then pull MRS. BROWN through. BERNIE, sputtering, is trying to get to his feet when the knock him down again in their frantic rush to get as far from the burning plane as they can. As BERNIE struggles to his feet yet again, more PASSENGER oozing out the door.  They brush him aside, splashing tow river bank, while orange flames are flickering wildly now the tail section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LESLIE is beside the exit, using her flashlight to guide Her face is bruised and bloody, her uniform torn, but she courage itself...

dialogues.text: Once you're outside, immediately move as far away from the aircraft as you can.  If you see someone who needs help... Scared PASSENGERS are struggling to get over the seats th close to where the floor ought to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, everybody, one at a time. Please, one at a time. Just then the young RICHIE, caught in the surge of PASSEN bumps into her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Miss, my father can't move. He can't move. LESLIE grabs him and shoves him bodily out the narrow exi she speaks urgently...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll try and help him, you wait outside.  Get as far away from the plane as you can. Just then LESLIE sees the bloody PILOT and CO-PILOT stagg toward her. She helps them out the narrow opening, half pushing them.

dialogues.text: BERNIE'S face is smeared with mud!  He staggers out of th in the flicker of firelight and starts searching for his on the muddy riverbank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna bUy me a new pair a shoes, pal? The sound of approaching SIRENS cuts through the rainy ni

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad!  Dad! He doesn't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in there!  He's hurt! In the plane?  In there?  BERNIE looks at the plane, reac

dialogues.text: In there?  Listen, kid, the cops are coming... and the firemen. They, uh, they got equipment and stuff for this kindathing, they're, uh, experts. The sound of SIRENS, still.  a ways off.  RICHIE clutches BERNIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, sir!  Please!  It's on fire. He can't move. BERNIE stares into the desperate face... and suddenly, recklessly, BERNIE loses it, forgets he's BERNIE, acts li someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside!  He's in the plane, he...

BERNIE finds himself standing in the choking darkness, PASSENGERS pushing past him.  Holy smokes!  This is ridic What's he doing here?  Thicker smoke, can barely see anyt VOICES cry out in pain and fear.  Just then he spots some A flashlight lies on the floor sending a useless knife of into the smoky darkness.  He grabs for it, drops it urgen

BERNIE hesitates.  Then he leans down, still gripping the and half hauls FREDDY toward the nearby exit where LESLIE supervising PASSENGERS.

For half a second, LESLIE'S face reveals her amazement at somebody go back into the the nightmare a second time.  T she's helping the next passenger out... SUSAN and KELLY..

For a moment BERNIE'S face passes through the stationary of the flashlight and GALE gets a glimpse of a smoky, mud leaning close to her...AN OBSCURE VISION!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

It of her line of vision, behind her head.  He only hesitate half a second before his hand shoots out for the purse, c it under his jacket, and gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LESLIE is helping ANOTHER MAN out the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from the plane quickly. It may explode. Now she's alone.  Heroically she turns back and probes th interior with her flashlight. The blade of light is blunted by the smoky darkness.  The nothing. LESLIE hesitates.  Should she run, save her own life or.. Suddenly BERNIE steps into the beam of her light, emergin the thick smoke hauling GALE over his shoulder, his face smudged, unrecognizeable, AN HEROIC VISION SHE'LL REMEMBE

Then get down to the hospital and I'll do an interview and an intro and close.  Make sure... BANG!  The PARAMEDICS slam the door behind her. CONKLIN shakes his head as CHUCKY lowers his camera and t ambulance pulls away.

dialogues.text: She's a real piece of work! Unbelievable!  "It's 'my story, I did the research."

dialogues.text: reacting with sudden horror at something he sees.

dialogues.text: The spot where BERNIE left his car.  FIREMEN are spraying retardant on the firey fuselage of the plane.  No sign of car!

dialogues.text: Christ!  My car!  Where's my car? BERNIE moans mournfully and suddenly a STATE POLICE OFFIC is at his side.

dialogues.text: Huh?  Hurt?  What? BERNIE is urgently concerned with the purse poorly concea under his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I don't need no ambulance. I'm just looking for my car... It musta burned up or something. The purse is visible though the OFFICER hasn't yet notice He's patronizing BERNIE, insisting.

dialogues.text: Please, please, my husband's been waiting for medical attention... As she pulls the OFFICER away, BERNIE hides the purse dee under his coat, breathes a sigh of relief... and notices something!

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Limping up to his car, wiping the foam off the windshield

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERNIE is getting out of his Toyota in the glow of a streetlight.  It's still raining.  BERIE is soaking wet, wiping off his face.  He trudges toward the house wearing one shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waited for you three hours!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not gonna believe this, Evelyn!  Absolutely fantastic!  I'm on my way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so tired of your bullshit, Bernie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ev, it's not my fault!  I'm trying to tell you this incredible --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's never your fault, Bernie! Never ever!  You screwed up my life, now you're gonna screw up Joey's life, but you're never gonna accept responsibility for anyth--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he here, your friend.  The fireman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had an emergency call... a real emergency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why doncha let me in so we don't wake everybody in the neighborhood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suburban.  Inexpensive furniture.  EVELYN and BERNIE rant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willya lemme talk for Chrissake? I'm trying to tell you what happened.  What happened is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same thing that always happens! You blew it! And this time you broke your son's heart instead of mine!  He was so proud, looking forward to going to a movie with his father... and you let him down!  Like you let everybody down, always!  What did you do, take a mudbath?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: eyes wide, crouched at the top of the staircase in his py spying on his parents in the living room below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm trying to... to... okay, nevermind.  Just lemme talk to Joey to... to apologize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in bed!  You're not gonna wake him and make him crazy, do you understand?  He comes home from the zoo, he wants to know if Elliot's a "war hero" like you... he wants to know how many people you killed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Elliot"?  The heroic goddamn fireman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to explain your tendancy to "exaggerate", How you were actually "in country" all of two weeks and how you killed about as many people as the other clerk-typists in your outfit, no more, no less...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three weeks, Ev.  I didn't tell him I killed anybody...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe not,... but you let him believe it!  And then I gotta explain about the homeless...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The homeless!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How not all of them own apartment complexes, how not all of them play the stock market, how not all of them rent babies when they're panhandling.  He's ten years old, Bernie!  Impressionable!

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Watching from the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, it's important, Ev, I gotta see him, I got my reasons, very goddamn important...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use the phone, Bernie, call him tomorrow, he'd like to hear from you.  Where's your other shoe? Never mind!  I don't want to know. Some fantastic adventure, right? Something really crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was giving him some advice is all. Preparing him for life.  You don't want him to grow up soft, Ev        , it's tough out there, it's a goddamn jungle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly, opening the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the jungle, Bernie.  Good night.

He reaches dow takes the purse, rummages in it, pulls out the Silver Mik glances at it, might be worth something, pockets it moves to the wallet, the credit cards, the cash... some hundred fifties', twenties...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Ev, to bother you again. This is for Joey, his reward... for this wallet he found.  When I, uh , returned it I told the guy he hadda give my kid something for finding it, for the honesty.  So the kid would learn how honestly pays. Eyes meet.  She doesn't believe it for a moment and he kn it.

Looking for the VOICES, we MOVE IN on a single lane of cr traffic and finally FOCUS ON a battered, rusted 76 Chevy a crumpled fender, a trunk tied closed and cracked window

dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.text: And you pulled people out? You're...  a hero.

dialogues.text: Nah, I fucked it up.  I was tryin' to impress this kid, don't ask me why.  I was gonna rescue his old man, but I couldn't find the poor bastard.  He musta blew up. (then...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the hell outta there.  I didn't have the nerve to face the kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtful, serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Try stupid. BUBBER brakes for traffic and a cardboard box from the ba hits BERNIE and cascades crushed cans all over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about that.  Just toss them in back. (very serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of people would say that's what heroism is... stupidity.  Doing something that if you thought about it, you wouldn't do it, it's not in your...  interest. BERNIE indicates the clutter of cans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a drinking problem or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sell them at the recycling center. Gives me a little for gas and food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (considering the back seat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like you live in here, for Chrissake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In bad weather, yeah.  Mostly I camp out in the woods.  I thought maybe you were down on your luck too when I picked you up. BUBBER indicates BERNIE'S muddy, torn clothes, stocking f

dialogues.text: You should give it to someone with only one leg.

dialogues.text: One leg!  Like the Red Cross or something?

dialogues.text: I got a job, nice apartment.  I do okay.

dialogues.text: They interview you or anything? At the plane crash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, do I look crazy?  I don't go for that shit... interviews, media. They're manipulators.  "Keep a low profile," that's my motto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chevy inches forward as the traffic moves again, head slowly toward the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing, grandly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, I got these legal problems. My attorney don't want me giving statements to the press. Traffic is still crawling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.  You can't find him? She stares incredulously at her trio of visitors, CONKLIN CHUCKY, and DEAKINS.  DEAKINS, uncomfortable outside his office, is awkwardly trying to vase a bouquet of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lot of confusion around what went on last night, it's not clear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said all the passengers were accounted for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently the guy who pulled you out wasn't a passenger... A NURSE gracefully relieves DEAKINS of the flowers he's destroying and skillfully vases them while GALE questions

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A paramedic?  A fireman?  He didn't have a uniform...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what we could get, there's a kind of... sort of... "mystery guy"...  involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're piecing together different accounts and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A "mystery guy!"  "Not a passenger." Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know who he is, he...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A non-passenger, non-rescue-worker went into a burning plane and pulled me out and... disappeared? GALE starts to get up, struggling with covers, I.V., etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not just you.  Apparently this guy is the one who opened the emergency exit from the outside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody! He saved everybody on the plane! Because of him, no fatalities!  I don't think you're supposed to move around like that, Gale.  You're attached there... GALE is getting out of bed, the I.V. still inserted in he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what gave me the courage to hang in there even though I knew the plane could blow any minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. SMITH is being interviewed in his bed.  He's emotiona

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just this face, all dirty, it just appeared.  I really thought I was going to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say anything to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He... asked if I was "Fletcher."

dialogues.text: A man named ROBINSON, fifty, sloppy, screams apoplectical

dialogues.text: Bill, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Disheveled, in stocking feet, BERNIE trudges wearily up t front steps of the shabby apartment house where he lives, enters.

dialogues.text: Posters, youthy icons.  CHUCKY shooting GALE interviewing

dialogues.text: He said... uh... he said... (not sure, thinking, then... )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SCREEN, (EXT. AIRPLANE - NIGHT)
dialogues.text: A tiny silhouetted FIGURE appears in the far right corner the frame.  Then, as one more frame clicks off, the FIGUR appears near the center of the next frame of the pan. The picture freezes there, a startling dramatic image of UNRECOGNIZABLE FIGURE (BERNIE) in silhouette, dwarfed by gigantic explosion.  IT'S AN AWESOME IMAGE.  NO ARTIST OR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else?  We've accounted for everyone else.  That's our hero! She stares at "The Image."  It's powerful, stirring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see the guy when I shot it.  I thought I was getting the last survivors when I panned over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any chance we could do some kind of electronic enhancement, you think?  Get a clear picture, identify him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (peering closely at the screen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no face really, nothing to work with.  Big dots, that's all you'll get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the guy!  He just saved fifty people.  Now he's going to disappear. Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UUUUHHHHOOOOOOOW!  BERNIE snores loudly, asleep on his so still in his rumpled, torn clothes.  He SNORES again.

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO IMAGE
dialogues.text: ON THE SCREEN, RICHIE is talking directly at the CAMERA, interview in his room on videotape...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said... uh, he said... "I'll save your father."

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO IMAGE
dialogues.text: LESLIE appears ON SCREEN, her interview...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- all of a sudden, this... civilian...  He rushed into the plane.

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO IMAGE
dialogues.text: Freddy appears talking directly at the CAMERA...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I woke up in an ambulance.  Leslie, the other flight attendant, told me the guy dragged me to the exit.

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO IMAGE
dialogues.text: Leslie appears ON THE SCREEN again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Here, give this guy a hand," he said.  The next thing I knew, he was going back in there, into all that smoke...

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO IMAGE
dialogues.text: MR. SMITH appears ON THE SCREEN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was crawling around on the floor. I thought I was a goner!

dialogues.speaker: DENTISTS, BLACK PEOPLE, BROWN PEOPLE, WHITE PEOPLE, CHINE
dialogues.text: PEOPLE are watching the report in...

dialogues.speaker: -SHADOW LOUNGE
dialogues.text: CHICK watching the report.

dialogues.speaker: -CLASSROOM
dialogues.text: JOEY watching the report in a classroom.

dialogues.speaker: -EVELYN'S KITCHEN
dialogues.text: EVELYN watching the report in her kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: -ALLEY
dialogues.text: BUBBER is listening to the report on a radio in an alley.

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO IMAGE
dialogues.text: GALE, bandaged, casted, stands in front of a BLUE SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- out of the darkness... out of the smoke and the fear... came a man with no name... no uniform... but an abundance of courage. The CAMERA ZOOMS IN SLOWLY on GALE and simultaneously DIS SLOWLY TO... "THE IMAGE".  It fills the screen as GALE na VOICEOVER...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man who was thinking not about himself but about others, risking his own life for ours... (a beat then...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's out there now somewhere... and... whoever you are, I, and the other survivors of Flight 104, say, "Thank you!  God bless!" MUSIC SWELLS as the CAMERA ZOOMS IN on "THE IMAGE" emphas the tiny FIGURE alone in the frame surrounded by fire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flanked by GALE and CHUCKY, DEAKINS is watching the prece material on the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad.  But if you gotta wear a cast, you oughtta feature it more it's parta the story. (seeing Wallace enter the room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Network's taking everything we give 'em.  They wanta feed off our six o'clock whether we find the mystery guy or not.  We're very big nationally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a wonderful piece.  Emotional. I love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna feature Gale's cast more.  The trick is gonna be keeping the upper hand on this piece. As long as we have Gale and there's no mystery guy, we're the center of the story.  But if he shows up and somebody else gets him first or exclusive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about a reward for coming forward? DEAKINS answers a RINGING phone.  GALE frowns, frets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There could be problems with something like that Mister Wallace. What if...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: WHAT
dialogues.text: Everybody looks at DEAKINS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignoring the open schoolbook on the floor in front of him is sprawled on the floor, eyes on the TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: A CLOSE-UP of a muddy shoe WIDENS to REVEAL the shoe nest in GALE'S sling on top of her cast.  She addresses the ca from a spot directly in front of the crash site while beh her WORKMEN comb the wreckage under bright halogen lights

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A phone check with survivors has confirmed that the shoe does not belong to any of the crew or passengers of Flight 104.  Several witnesses recall the mysterious man who saved fifty-four people referring to his missing shoe. The conclusion; the unknown hero, know to many as "The Angel of Flight 104," wears a size 10B shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey!  Dinner!  Now!  Turn that thing off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT is at the table with EVELYN as JOEY joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lost a shoe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who lost a shoe?  Wash your hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "unknown hero."  They found his shoe right beside the plane crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Superman, you mean?  Lost a shoe! What next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elliot!  The man saved hundreds of people!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-four!  I was there, remember? You know why I didn't rush into that plane?  Because I'm a trained fireman, that's why!  Part of a team!  A disciplined team.  We take risks all the time, save people. But we don't take crazy chances. This guy does something really dumb and he lucks out.  So the media go crazy about his shoe for god's sake! What kind of message are they giving to youth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Joey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of message are you giving to youth?  Sneering at someone for sticking his neck out.  You sound like my ex for heaven's sake... Mister Cynicism. ELLIOT gets up, shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what can I say?  Give your ex credit for being smart enough not to do something stupid.  Maybe the man's not all bad.  I'm gonna watch TV, hoping it's not all this "Superman stuff." ELLIOT walks over to the TV and turns it on, leaving JOEY EVELYN alone.  JOEY is excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father didn't have his shoes on when he... when he came here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were in bed.  Weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I saw him out the window. EVELYN frowns, hesitates a moment.  Was the kid listening Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think your father would do something like that?  Rescue people? (sadly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father is Bernie LaPlante, Joey.  It's against his religion to stick his neck out.

dialogues.speaker: THE TV, (INT. NEWS SET - NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Where an ANCHORPERSON speaks from a news set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- where the leader of a religious group claimed today that the mysterious hero is, in fact, an angel who is anticipated in scripture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washing glasses behind the bar, CHICK is watching the sam on the TV over the bar when he turns to see BERNIE enter (wearing a brand new pair of cheap running shoes.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernie, how'sa kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't wanna know, Chick, you don't wanna know.  Those guys been in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouring a 7&7)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You in business with those guys or what?  I wouldn't want a problem for the establishment, Bern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't have a problem, Chick, because I personally have got them all.  I cornered the whole goddamn market.  You wouldn't believe... Oh, how ya doin'...? ESPINOSA and VARGAS have entered the bar. They have anoth with them, MENDOZA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We bring our frenn this time, okay? Something about MENDOZA spells trouble. it's almost palpa BERNIE doesn't notice, but CHICK does.  He looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me here, Chick, I gotta do these guys a little favor.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: As BERNIE, MENDOZA and ESPINOSA slide into a booth intent business, ESPINOSA looks around for VARGAS and spots him lingering back at the bar watching the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out to Vargas)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, vato!  Vamos.

dialogues.speaker: THE BAR
dialogues.text: Where VARGAS and CHICK are staring at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: THE TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: Where the ANCHORPERSON is introducing WALLACE who stands in a suit and tie looking ill at ease...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- bring you a special announcement from Channel Four station Manager, James Wallace. Framed alone now, WALLACE smiles awkwardly at the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening.  We at Channel Four, like you, have been stirred by the courage and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hombre!  Por aqui!

dialogues.speaker: VARGAS
dialogues.text: Eyes lingering on the TV, backing toward the booth.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: BERNIE has spread GALE'S credit cards on the table in fro ESPINOSA and MENDOZA.  ESPINOSA examines them, questions BERNIE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many you got there?  Eight? Ten? VARGAS slides into the booth before BERNIE can answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They offer him a million dollars reward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "plane crash guy".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bernie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all of them?  Eight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What "plane crash guy"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one-shoe dude who saved all those people, man.  Channel Four gonna give him a million for an interview. ESPINOSA tries to turn BERNIE'S attention back to "busine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come.  on, hombre, we doin' business here.  You got more or not?

dialogues.speaker: CHICK
dialogues.text: Watching the TV

dialogues.text: Where WALLACE is concluding...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The offer is absolutely unconditional.  All he has to do, is satisfy our reporter, Gale Gayley, and the other passengers who had contact with him that he is indeed the brave man who...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling)

dialogues.speaker: CHICK
dialogues.text: Turning, seeing a commotion at the booth.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOOTH
dialogues.text: Where MENDOZA is handcuffing the outraged BERNIE while ES reads him his rights...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the right to remain silent, you have the right to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, this is bullshit!  Do you guys know who I am?  You know where I got the goddamn plastic?  I got a million bucks coming.  I'm the guy who...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the right to the counsel of an attorney...

dialogues.speaker: CHICK
dialogues.text: Watching BERNIE being hustled out of the bar, handcuffed, protesting loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newspapers roll off the presses one after another. THE TIMES features "The Image" with a headline over the f scene trumpeting "AN ANGEL FOR FLIGHT 104?" THE MIRROR is tighter on the image featuring an enlargeme the silhouette of Bernie with a headline asking "WHO IS H THE HERALD features a full page photo of the single muddy with a headline supered over it announcing "SEARCH FOR MR

dialogues.text: and finally THE TRIBUNE screams in massive black letters

dialogues.text: A NEWS VENDOR is waving a paper and shouting...

dialogues.speaker: PEOPLE AND TOOK OFF
dialogues.text: A WOMAN walks by with a tee-shirt featuring "The Image." spectacular picture looks great on the contours of her ch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARKER, the youthful Channel Four gofer/runner, moves alo seemingly endless line of WANNABE HEROES that stretches a the sidewalk outside Channel Four and disappears around t corner.  He's addressing them at the top of his lungs...

dialogues.speaker: ONLY SEEING SIZE 10-B "HEROES."
dialogues.text: GROANS and CATCALLS from the WANNABES, as we MOVE ALONG t eavesdropping on various WANNABES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thass a racist perspective, assuming that because something heroic was done that a white man done it.  A man with mud on his face could be a man of any color, most likely was, which is true in this case cause it was me!  With mud all over me. Two other WANNABES are squaring off to fight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call me a liar, I'm gonna kick your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's not just me sayin' you ain't no hero.  Everybody in the goddamn line says you ain't the hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe this?  Must be more than a thousand phonies after my reward. A WANNABE with mud smeared on his face spots GALE approac the front door of the station, a look of amazement on her at the length of the line.

dialogues.speaker: YOUR LIFE
dialogues.text: Rolling her eyes good naturedly, GALE walks briskly up th to the front door of the station, passing PARKER who's me a TALL WANNABE'S feet.  The TALL WANNABE calls out to her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My foot's only eight and a half but I wear a ten B for the comfort. I swear! (she keeps walking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Miss Gayley, I saved your life! Just as GALE is about to enter the TV station, PARKER cat up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Miss Gayley, there's a cop looking for you.  From Robbery Detail, Inspector Dayton.  He wants you to call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't ask him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call him back.  Ask him. (indicating the line)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little...busy. GALE disappears into the TV Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALLACE is looking down at the line of WANNABES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE GOINES is addressing a miserable looking CRIMINAL..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bail in this matter will remain in the sum of five thousand dollars.  Next.

dialogues.speaker: DISCOVER MENDOZA, ESPINOSA AND VARGAS
dialogues.text: carrying on a whispered discussion with an African Americ detective (DAYTON) in the spectator section (AS THE COURT PROCEEDINGS CONTINUE IN THE BACKGROUND).  MENDOZA indicat something at the rear of the room to DAYTON who follows h look. DAYTON'S P.O.V. A group of PRISONERS have just been led in the side door a holding cell and a BAILIFF is removing the handcuffs th tied the PRISONERS together.  One of the PRISONERS is BER LAPLANTE.  DONNA approaches him as the BAILIFF uncuffs hi She speaks to him but her words are inaudible to DAYTON.

dialogues.speaker: DAYTON
dialogues.text: as he watches BERNIE from a distance, nods affirmatively something MENDOZA whispers in his ear.  We realize we'll seeing DAYTON again...

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: astonished, reacting to BERNIE in a sharp whisper...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Angel of Flight 104!"  You're telling me you're the A...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Angel!"  I didn't say "angel," that's a little strong.  Listen, here's the thing, I gotta get over there to the TV station to collect my million bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister LaPlante, I really want to help you, but crazy stories are only going to make it worse.  The D.A. is asking your bail be set at twenty-five thousand dollars because you were arrested again while you were out on bail...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five grand is peanuts!  All you gotta do is get me outta here long enough to collect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The People versus Bernard LaPlante. JUDGE GOINES scowls at the sight of BERNIE moving toward talking already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your honor, my attorney here says the prosecutor there wants twenty-five grand bail... DONNA looks horrified, the JUDGE furious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister LaPlante, you will be silent unless the court recognizes you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing grandly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --which is fine by me.  I got no problem with that at all. In fact, your honor, I'd be proud to double it.  Fifty grand!  A tip for "the people," your honor, if I could just... GOINES is banging his gavel angrily, glaring at BERNIE, n noticing a SECOND BAILIFF hurry into the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister LaPlante, unless you stop chattering immediately, I am going to ask the Bailiff to... JUDGE GOINES breaks off, eyes furious, as he spots BAILIF the Court Reporter, DE TAGLIO and the SECOND BAILIFF enga in urgent whispering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, your honor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got carried away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They found him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Found who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "Angel of Flight 104".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was on the news!  Just now! He's gonna be on Channel Four at noon! BERNIE reacts, jaw sagging in disbelief.  The JUDGE sneak hasty look at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll sustain bail at twenty-five thousand dollars.  That ought to keep Mister LaPlante out of trouble for a minute or two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But your honor, my client is a responsible family man with limited resources who...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But finally you did come forward. Why? BUBBER looks her right in the eyes, gives a sheepish grin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The money, Gale.  I wouldn't have come forward at all if it wasn't for the reward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut right there, right on that look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVEAL GALE in an editing room looking over editor JOAN'S shoulder as JOAN freezes the image and makes a note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
